body:
This line:

>` import deeplabcut (2021-08-31 10:59:50.660626: I tensorflow/stream_executor/platform/default/dso_loader.cc:44] Successfully opened dynamic library cudart64_101.dll)`

suggests that you don't have all of the proper parts for CUDA 11 (it's using a 10.1 library).  In that case, your training is running on your CPU, not your GPU, and it could take a while to run 1000 iterations  (your `display_iters`) before showing anything.

To fix, I suggest the following:
1. As per the full [installation instructions](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/installation.md),  under **GPU support**, activate your env, and run `conda install -c conda-forge cudnn`. That should fix the initial problem (that message should show something like `cudart64_11.dll`).
2. Start your training again, but change `display_iters` to something like 1 or 10.  That way you'll get faster feedback to ensure that training is actually happening, and the code isn't stuck before it starts running iterations.
3. To see if your GPU is really being used, the best way on windows is to look at the GPU memory on the "Performance" tab of Windows task manager (see discussion [here](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1485#issuecomment-909174928)). You have only 8GB of GPU memory, and a training session should probably take most of that (depending on image size, batch size, etc). GPU memory gets allocated when training starts, and stays high during training. You can also look at the CUDA performance there, which for me oscillates up and down during training.

I just ran `conda install -c conda-forge cudnn` and I also added the correct CUDnn components to the CUDA 11 (cudnn64_8.dll; cudnn.h; cudnn.lib) but it still seems like it's trying to use CUDA 10.1 as I still get the line `Successfully opened dynamic library cudart64_101.dll` after importing deeplabcut to ipython

I just now updated a 2.2rc3 env to 2.2.0.1 (from the repo) on my windows machine with a GPU.
Unfortunately, I don't get the "Successfully opened...dll" messages (I may have muted them somehow?), but the testscript definitely engaged my GPU.

In case it helps the output of my env for `conda list` is below:

Compare your cudatoolkit, cudnn, and tensorflow versions to that, since I know that works.

The output from `nvcc -V` is 

```
nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2021 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Wed_Jun__2_19:25:35_Pacific_Daylight_Time_2021
Cuda compilation tools, release 11.4, V11.4.48
Build cuda_11.4.r11.4/compiler.30033411_0
```

and `nvidia-smi` shows ` Driver Version: 471.11       CUDA Version: 11.4` (my card is a Quadro RTX 6000, so driver will vary for your).

I just noticed that your driver is 451.*. I'm not sure about your card and driver, but there's a chance that your driver doesn't fully support tensorflow 2+ and CUDA 11+.  You should investigate updating your driver (or at least compatibility of your existing driver with the above).

I updated both my driver and Cuda to `NVIDIA-SMI 471.96       Driver Version: 471.96       CUDA Version: 11.4`
and I compared my entire `conda list` and the only differences are that `numpy =  1.21.2` `opencv-python-headless = 3.4.9.33` and `tensorboard = 2.2.2` `tensorflow = 2.2.0` `tensorflow estimator = 2.2.0`

When I try to update tensorflow to 2.6.0 I get the error message `deeplabcut 2.2.0.1 requires numpy>=1.21, but you have numpy 1.19.5 which is incompatible.`

to reverse this I do `pip install --upgrade deeplabcut` which reverts tensorboard to  2.2.2 and tensorflow to 2.2.0

Lastly when I open ipython and try to import deeplabcut after this, I get the message `2021-08-31 17:14:26.086991: W tensorflow/stream_executor/platform/default/dso_loader.cc:55] Could not load dynamic library 'cudart64_101.dll'; dlerror: cudart64_101.dll not found
2021-08-31 17:14:26.089265: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cudart_stub.cc:29] Ignore above cudart dlerror if you do not have a GPU set up on your machine.` which is weird since I updated everything yet it's still looking for CUDA 10.1

issue.title: Unpin numpy

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Unpin numpy in order for tensorflow >= 2.2 to function.

Fixes #1486 #1487

body: @bgibWh, that makes sense. Tensorflow 2.2 looks for cuda 10.1, whereas cuda>=11 only works for tf >= 2.3. The fix is to unpin numpy in setup.py, so it won't complain that tensorflow is trying to install numpy 1.19.5.
unpinned numpy now you can install from git!: https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/recipes/installTips.html#how-to-use-the-latest-updates-directly-from-github

rename.to: Training doesn't reach first iteration -- due to CUDA/TF version mismatch causes by pinned numpy

body:
I've installed via git but still get the message `ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
deeplabcut 2.2.0.1 requires numpy>=1.21, but you have numpy 1.19.5 which is incompatible.` when I install tensorflow to match my CUDA `pip install tensorflow==2.4.1` 

It allows me to start training in ipython but my GPU usage on task manager is basically 0% while the dedicated memory usage of my GPU increases but I can leave it overnight for days without getting a single visible iteration. Not sure why but it just doesn't seem like my GPU is being fully utilized for training. Any help would be greatly appreciated

issue.title: Issues still due to CUDA/TF version mismatch causes by pinned numpy

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Bug description

Previously have had help with this issue (https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1487#issuecomment-911410142) (https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1487#issue-983975370)

And I followed the advice by installing via git but still get the message `ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts. deeplabcut 2.2.0.1 requires numpy>=1.21, but you have numpy 1.19.5 which is incompatible.` when I install tensorflow to match my CUDA `pip install tensorflow==2.4.1`

It allows me to start training in ipython but my GPU usage on task manager is basically 0% while the dedicated memory usage of my GPU increases but I can leave it overnight for days without getting a single visible iteration. Not sure why but it just doesn't seem like my GPU is being fully utilized for training. Any help would be greatly appreciated

### Operating System

Windows 10.0.18362
python 3.8
CUDA 11.0

### DeepLabCut version

dlc version= 2.2.0.1

### DeepLabCut mode

single animal

### Device type

GeForce RTX 2080 SUPER

### Steps To Reproduce

1. `pip install tensorflow==2.4.1`
2. `ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
deeplabcut 2.2.0.1 requires numpy>=1.21, but you have numpy 1.19.5 which is incompatible.`

### Relevant log output

body:
In your env, try:

```
pip install --upgrade --upgrade-strategy eager git+https://github.com/deeplabcut/deeplabcut.git
```

that should update numpy to 1.21, TF to 2.6, and deeplabcut to the latest master on GitHub.
I did that but still got the error message `deeplabcut 2.2.0.1 requires numpy>=1.21, but you have numpy 1.19.5 which is incompatible.`

Here's everything I get when I did that:

After that I did `pip install tensorflow_gpu==2.6.0` to resolve the first set of issues but still seems to be a numpy issue when I try training

Numpy didn't update (it knows it needs 1.21 and uses a downloaded version, but doesn't actually update it) based on your log.

`pip install numpy==1.21`

If that doesn't work, sometimes the pip references in an environment can get scrambled after so much fiddling.
Delete your env with `conda env remove -n DEEPLABCUT`

Then download the latest DEEPLABCUT.yaml from GitHub (if you cloned the repo, that one should be good enough).
Open it in a text editor and on the last line replace 

```
"deeplabcut[gui]"
```

with

```
git+https://github.com/deeplabcut/deeplabcut.git
```

Save the file, then use it to create a new env.

I uninstalled it and changed the YAML file like you said from a cloned version I downloaded today

I created a new environment from that YAML file in anaconda and opened terminal and ran `pip install numpy==1.21` and received the error message `ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
tensorflow 2.6.0 requires numpy~=1.19.2, but you have numpy 1.21.0 which is incompatible.
numba 0.54.0 requires numpy<1.21,>=1.17, but you have numpy 1.21.0 which is incompatible.`

I then went to ipython and ran `import deeplabcut` and got this:
